author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->
I suggest renaming the package to some more descriptive name involving clustering.
PrototypesCriticisms.jl makes no allusion to statistics at all. (BTW, we already have packages for clustering).

> I suggest renaming the package to some more descriptive name involving clustering.

Thank you for the suggestion. That would be too restrictive because the package is not limited to the computation of prototypes and criticisms for clusterings. [noblock]

> PrototypesCriticisms.jl makes no allusion to statistics at all. (BTW, we already have packages for clustering).

Is it necessary for packages to use statistical methods? I may not understand the comment. Anyway, the package does not implement any new clustering algorithms. Instead, it provides (among other things) interfaces to some types of Clustering.jl. [noblock]

It is just the naming that is confusing and will likely render your package
undiscoverable. Also, what is the rationale for creating a wrapper package
with clustering methods that already exist in a established package? Did
you miss a feature in Clustering.jl?

Em ter., 31 de mai. de 2022 03:55, Lars Schütz ***@***.***>
escreveu:

> PrototypesCriticisms.jl makes no allusion to statistics at all. (BTW, we
> already have packages for clustering).
>
> Is it necessary for packages to use statistical methods? I may not
> understand the comment. Anyway, the package does not implement any new
> clustering algorithms. Instead, it provides (among other things) interfaces
> to some types of Clustering.jl. [noblock]
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/61167#issuecomment-1141735718>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAZQW3KFKQWF6FI4LMJDVNTVMWZUVANCNFSM5XECAQ4A>
> .
> You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

> It is just the naming that is confusing and will likely render your package undiscoverable. Also, what is the rationale for creating a wrapper package with clustering methods that already exist in a established package? Did you miss a feature in Clustering.jl?

I disagree that the name is confusing. Also, this is not a wrapper package with clustering methods. Please consider the few interfaces just as an easy access to the methods that follow. The package can also do completely without these interfaces. [noblock]

I decided to change the focus of the package so that it mainly looks at clustering results only. Raw data sets do not matter anymore.Then a name change would be appropriate. However, there will still be no new clustering algorithms or similar. Please close this pull request. Eventually, I will create a new pull request in the future.

This pull request has been inactive for 30 days and will be automatically closed 7 days from now. If this pull request should not be closed, please either (1) fix the AutoMerge issues and re-trigger Registrator, which will automatically update the pull request, or (2) post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. [noblock]
This pull request has been inactive for more than 30 days and has automatically been closed. Feel free to register your package or version again once you fix the AutoMerge issues. [noblock]
